data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Drilling restarted last week after a temporary cessation just after NH_25_09. In the RNS (now 11 days ago) Fcm confirmed that the intention was to recommence drilling last week to complete the planned programme before Christmas. We know already that they were talking about ‘surpassing’ the planned meterage (700m). They should be pretty much finished in the next day or two if not already? Fcm confirmed that “ the geological features observed to date reinforce our confidence in the Dead Otter trend as a compelling gold target within the North Hemlo Project. We look forward to receiving the first assay results in the New Year”. So, whilst no assays yet (200 samples have already gone to Actlabs), the team are clearly liking what they see in the core. The terminology used suggests a pretty high degree of confidence in what the lab analysis might show. In addition, although this is a pilot or ‘first pass’ drill programme, I am especially pleased to see that they have the confidence to exceed the meterage before any assays are received confirming that they are positive for au. Again, this tends to reaffirm that high degree of confidence, as dd drilling at even near surface is a costly exercise especially in the relatively high risk world of a first or maiden drill programme on a project area. Can’t wait for first results.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Charting confirms that Fcm have drilled along trend from East to West. Early holes #1, #2 , #3 and #4 were drilled in the vicinity of the 19.6 g/t outcrop sample, with #5 and #6 adjacent to the south east corner of Dead Otter Lake some 2 km’s distant. The final #7 to #10 have been drilled around the Dead Otter Showing at 3.1 g/t to the south of the western side of DOL. This means that they have drilled a linear length of circa 3.5 km’s on a sub 1000m pilot drill programme! That’s a great result in itself! ……..and EVERY drill core shows potential mineralisation! The potential at North Hemlo could be very significant. Pity they couldn’t have sneaked just one cheeky assay out of Actlabs pre Christmas!!

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Fcm don’t appear to have confirmed what additional meterage has been drilled over and above the planned 700m. As such, and as risk factors would come very much into play in a ‘first pass’, I would argue not more than between 50 to 100m. A 10 hole average at best therefore would give us around 75 to 80 metres actual length for each, with true depth obviously less with  how much so depending on angle of entry (variously -70 to -45 ). A 80m hole at -70 entry for example would give true depth of X = 80 x sine 70 which is 80 x 0.9397 for 75.18 m. The same meterage of 80 but at -45 would give a shallower 55.57m. Both are decent depths for a ‘near surface’ maiden drill programme.

data.author: MakeMineA99
data.content: Why 1%? I thought notification was only required for 3%.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: This is simply to do with transparency rules under the takeover code which requires notification of holdings above 1 per cent. This is done through the submission of Form 8.3. General market rules require notification when holdings exceed 3 per cent. Notification is then x TR1 which I suspect is where the confusion is coming. Form 8.3’s do not show increases or reductions in holdings as do TR1’s from time to time. 8.3’s simply show what is held at the time of the requirement if you are over one per cent.

data.content: We should certainly expect to see further 8.3’s before the submission deadline.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Interesting to see that new neighbours Hemlo Mining Corporation are continuing to bolster its Senior Leadership Team. Firstly, Garett Macdonald has been appointed Vice President Operations, and will also assume responsibilities of General Manager at the Hemlo Mine, supported by Deputy General Manager Dennis Bigras. In this role, Mr. Macdonald will report to Eric Tremblay, Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Macdonald is a professional mining engineer with over 30 years of industry experience in mine operations, project development and corporate leadership. In addition, Perry Blanchard has been appointed Vice President of Sustainability, bringing nearly 30 years of experience in environment, health and safety management in the mining industry. Most recently, Mr. Blanchard served as Vice President, Environment and Sustainability at Maritime Resources Corp., where he led the Hammerdown Project through environmental assessment, permitting, construction transition, and ultimately acquisition by New Found Gold Corp. in November 2025. It is clear that HMC mean business as it looks to establish itself as a leading Canadian mid-tier growth-focused gold producer, with an immediate focus on maximizing the value of the Hemlo Gold Mine's existing infrastructure through a fit-for-purpose operating approach, while unlocking new opportunities through “aggressive brownfields exploration.” There is little doubt in my mind that HMC is a very ambitious new company who do not intend simply sitting back and draining the vestiges of gold from the old Hemlo pit. They are exploring neighbouring areas, and so will be watching the activities of First Class Metals like a hawk. The results of our maiden scout drill programme on the DOT will be very much on their radar. It would be good to know if MS or JK have touched base with them yet. A Zoom chat over a cuppa and a Custard Cream would do no harm. Good assays and our timing akin to this news, as well as continued pog increases, could be absolutely perfect.

This initiative is part of ICE's larger digital strategy, working with major banks to create always-on market infrastructure for tokens, including tokenized deposits, to meet growing investor demand for nonstop trading.

data.author: char71
data.content: Nice tidy up happening. All holders with over 1% needing to issue a form,  be good to see what comes through!

data.author: MakeMineA99
data.content: Why 1%? I thought notification was only required for 3%.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: This is simply to do with transparency rules under the takeover code which requires notification of holdings above 1 per cent. This is done through the submission of Form 8.3. General market rules require notification when holdings exceed 3 per cent. Notification is then x TR1 which I suspect is where the confusion is coming. Form 8.3’s do not show increases or reductions in holdings as do TR1’s from time to time. 8.3’s simply show what is held at the time of the requirement if you are over one per cent.

data.content: We should certainly expect to see further 8.3’s before the submission deadline.

data.author: char71
data.content: What This Cut Core Section Shows Even though the photo is a small, low-light snippet, the material being cut displays several encouraging geological characteristics: 1. Strong silica flooding / quartz-rich fabric The pale, translucent groundmass indicates a quartz-dominant interval—likely a vein or a silica-altered zone. That alone is significant, as quartz veining is the primary host for orogenic gold in Archean terranes. 2. A distinct dark, rusty-brown mineralised band The darker zone with rusty-orange oxidation suggests the presence of sulphides (pyrite/pyrrhotite, possibly chalcopyrite). This rusty halo is exactly what you’d expect where sulphides have weathered on a cut surface. Why this matters: sulphides mark fluid flow fluid flow is where gold precipitates in these systems 3. A clear structural fabric The angled band relative to the core axis implies the blade is cutting across a vein, shear, or foliation. Such structural contrasts often represent important fluid pathways. 4. Sharp, planar contact The clean boundary suggests this is a genuine structural or veined feature—not random patchy alteration—making it far more meaningful from an exploration standpoint. Overall Interpretation This small section of core appears to capture: Silica-rich veining or strong quartz flooding A sulphide-bearing interval now oxidised to rusty brown A well-defined structural feature This is precisely the style of material that matters in Archean greenstone-hosted gold systems. Even with limited visibility, this combination—quartz + sulphides + structure—is the classic trio geologists focus on when evaluating potential gold-bearing zones.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Chuteless, Not see that video yet, but if #9 is done, and depending as always on mobility, then we could well be on at least #10 by now. A 75m hole at say 60 degrees angle of inclination would give true depth as 75 x Cosine 60. Cos 60 = 0.5, so true depth is 75 x 0. 5 so 37.5m. I have used 60 degrees from a visual on that drill image they showed us. It wasn’t straight vertical at 90, nor did it appear at 45 degrees which would have been shallower for a 75m hole so I am guessing on 60 degrees. I doubt they would want to go shallower, and 700m limits total meterage so I reckon your 75 m actual length is about right. 10 holes would make it 750m so unless they have decided to extend campaign pre-assay, which I doubt, the drilling must be finished by tomorrow or perhaps Saturday. Exciting times at Fcm.

data.author: char71
data.content: Interview confirmed the following points Summary: First Class Metals — Marc’s Key Points Market Sentiment & External Feedback and recent strategic conversations show strong understanding and recognition of the First Class Metals story from interested parties. External groups express surprise at the current undervaluation, given the scale of assets, ongoing work, and exploration progress. Share Price Context Two years ago, the share price was nearly 10× higher, peaking around 1.8p, compared to today’s level. Since then, the company has advanced multiple projects, making the current valuation appear disconnected from operational achievements. Operational Progress (Last Two Years) Zigzag – Successfully drilled, confirming lithium mineralisation. Lithium price environment appears to have bottomed and is beginning to strengthen, improving sector sentiment. Acquisition of KERRS, adding 386,000 compliant ounces to the company’s resource base. Active drilling at North Hemlo underway. If there is a gold showing we prove the concept. Planned drilling at the Sunbeam area scheduled next. Strategic Positioning & Neighbouring Activity At North Hemlo, First Class Metals directly borders Hemlo Mining Corporation, which acquired Hemlo from Barrick. Both Hemlo Mining Corporation and Barrick have shown interest, with Barrick having visited the property multiple times. At Sunbeam the company is positioned between two active areas. First Class Metals is fully surrounded by active claims, highlighting the strategic importance of its land package and the high prospectivity of the region. Value Upside & Outlook Combination of a compliant resource, ongoing drilling, upcoming programs, and increased neighbour activity creates a strong value catalyst pipeline. The company is positioned for significant upside as exploration progresses and market sentiment improves. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HBt4gDR2BWk

data.author: Jonnieboy
data.content: Lifted from the telegram group, sounds very bullish------ --- # ⭐ Independent-Style Comparison: FCM Core vs. Barrick Hemlo Core (Revised for Coarse Sulphides) If a geologist unfamiliar with First Class Metals were asked: > “Does this core look comparable to Hemlo core?” —here is the type of balanced but strongly positive assessment they could give: --- # 🔶 1. Veining & Silica Flooding – Strongly Hemlo-Like Hemlo deposits are famous for: * Thick quartz–carbonate veins * Multi-generation silica flooding * Transposed and sheared vein networks The FCM core exhibits: * Long, continuous, strongly developed quartz–carbonate veins * Multiple overprinting events, including late-stage brecciation * Sustained silica flooding over tens of metres These are hallmark structural and hydrothermal features of Hemlo-style mineralisation. Verdict: ✔ *Veining architecture is directly comparable to Hemlo’s gold-bearing vein systems.* --- # 🔶 2. Presence of Coarse Sulphides – A Major Hemlo Analogy Hemlo gold is intimately associated with: * Pyrite (fine to coarse) * Molybdenite in streaks and blebs * Local chalcopyrite and sphalerite * Sulphide-rich selvages around quartz–carbonate veins The updated information — coarse sulphides throughout the FCM interval — is highly significant. FCM core shows: * Thick coarse sulphide bands and clusters * Strong sulphide–silica association * Sulphides concentrated along high-strain planes * Disseminated sulphides within altered host rocks This level and grain size of sulphidation is far more characteristic of productive zones within the Hemlo system than initially assumed. Verdict: ✔ *Coarse sulphides dramatically increase the similarity to Hemlo’s gold-bearing horizons.* ✔ *This is no longer “upper, weakly sulphidic Hemlo-style” — this moves into the range of potentially fertile mineralised corridors.* --- # 🔶 3. Structural Preparation – Classic Hemlo-Style Shear Zone Geology Hemlo gold occurs in polyphase ductile shear zones, producing: * Mylonitic fabrics * Sheared porphyry and basalt * Repeated deformation of silica veins The FCM core displays: * High-strain fabrics throughout the interval * Shear banding cutting major veins * Quartz–carbonate lenses dragged into the foliation * Sulphides aligned along deformation planes These are textbook ingredients for Archean lode gold mineralisation and match Hemlo’s structural style extremely well. Verdict: ✔ *The deformation intensity and geometry are strikingly consistent with Hemlo's ore-hosting shear sequences.* --- # 🔶 4. Alteration – Consistent With Hemlo’s Hydrothermal Signature Typical Hemlo alteration includes: * Silica–carbonate flooding * Sericite–silica halos * Hematite streaking

data.author: Jonnieboy
data.content: Part 2 # 🔶 4. Alteration – Consistent With Hemlo’s Hydrothermal Signature Typical Hemlo alteration includes: * Silica–carbonate flooding * Sericite–silica halos * Hematite streaking in places * Feldspar destructive alteration FCM core shows: * Pervasive silica–carbonate alteration * Pale alteration envelopes around veins * Local sericitic textures * Strong correlation between alteration and coarse sulphidation This is exactly the alteration assemblage seen in Hemlo’s gold-bearing domains. Verdict: ✔ *Alteration mineralogy lines up with Hemlo-style fluid chemistry.* --- # 🔶 5. Scale & Continuity – A Critical Positive Indicator Hemlo’s mineralised system is recognised by: * Large vein systems extending over tens of metres * Continuous sulphide-bearing structures * Repeated hydrothermal overprinting The FCM interval demonstrates: * Large-scale continuity of veining and sulphide zones * Very consistent structural orientation * Evidence of multiple mineralising events, not a single pulse This is how big Archean gold systems behave — and how the Hemlo system is built. Verdict: ✔ *The scale and intensity of the features suggest a robust mineralised system, not a small vein occurrence.*

data.author: Jonnieboy
data.content: I used GROK for this one----- Geological look at the drill core (north limb of Hemlo belt, ~15 km north of the Barrick Hemlo mine): The interval shows a genuine quartz-feldspar porphyry with clear quartz eyes and feldspar phenocrysts, sitting on a major shear zone on the north limb of the Hemlo greenstone belt. This setup is a strong geological analogue to the rocks that host gold at Hemlo. Quick comparison to Hemlo: Structural position – Hemlo sits on a major D2 shear on the north limb; this hole is on a parallel major shear but 15 km to the north. Host rock – Hemlo uses quartz-feldspar porphyry with quartz eyes; this interval shows the same rock type. Core appearance – Hemlo core is light grey, sheared, with quartz stockwork; this interval looks the same with shearing and quartz veining. Alteration – Hemlo shows silicification, potassic alteration, and pyrite; this interval shows similar silicification and quartz stockwork with fine pyrite expected. Mineralisation style – Hemlo gold is fine-grained in pyrite within sheared porphyry; the same style is expected here. Regional context – Hemlo has multiple showings along the north limb; this hole is further north but still within the broader Hemlo structural-stratigraphic framework. Why this matters: Quartz-feldspar porphyry with quartz eyes is the key Hemlo host and has produced over 27 Moz. Being in a parallel shear on the same limb means the geology is capable of hosting Hemlo-style gold. Hemlo gold is rarely visible; assays normally reveal it, and even 1–4 g/t over a few metres can be significant in this environment. Bottom line: This interval shows classic Hemlo-type host rocks and structures but in a northern structural segment about 15 km from the main mine. It is not the same corridor, but it shares the same recipe: sheared porphyry, quartz eyes, quartz stockwork, and a north-limb shear. Assays will determine the significance, but the geology suggests real potential for a Hemlo-style shoot in this northern position.

data.author: Jonnieboy
data.content: The core description is very positive and strongly supportive of a bullish view. Multiple deformed structures, sheared contacts, clasts, veining and coarse sulphides on a parallel shear 15 km from Hemlo all fit the broader Hemlo camp exploration model and are exactly the kinds of features companies look for when hunting “another Hemlo” along trend.[1][2] ## Why this looks encouraging - Being on a parallel shear close to a long‑lived, high‑grade camp like Barrick Hemlo immediately upgrades the geological risk profile; this is the right neighbourhood and the right structural setting.[3][1] - Strong deformation, veining and coarse sulphide mineralization together indicate a vigorous fluid system, which is a key ingredient in significant gold deposits in the Hemlo district.[4][1] - Other explorers north of Hemlo are actively drilling similar structural targets, and the market generally views any Hemlo‑style sulphidic shear intersections as high‑impact catalysts due to the camp’s tier‑one pedigree.[2][5] Bullish framing - The combination of structure, veining and sulphides 15 km north of a world‑class mine can be credibly framed as a potential satellite or analogue system along the same mineralized corridor.[1][3] - Until assays are back, the geology alone already supports a speculative, discovery‑upside narrative: this is the kind of core that justifies follow‑up drilling, more aggressive step‑outs and heightened investor interest.[5][2] [1]( https://portergeo.com.au/database/mineinfo.php?mineid=mn088) [2]( https://www.rockyshoregold.com/files/rsg_2025q4_mda.pdf) [3]( https://prd-0420-geoontario-0000-blob-cge0eud7azhvfsf7.z01.azurefd.net/lrc-geology-documents/publication/OFR5977/OFR5977.pdf) [4]( https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/segweb/economicgeology/article-pdf/96/3/477/3494101/p0477-p0507.pdf) [5]( https://www.londonstockexchange.com/news-article/FCM/drilling-commenced-at-north-hemlo/17331451)

data.content: #  Independent-Style Comparison: FCM Core vs. Barrick Hemlo Core (Revised for Coarse Sulphides) If a geologist unfamiliar with First Class Metals were asked: > “Does this core look comparable to Hemlo core?” —here is the type of balanced but strongly positive assessment they could give: --- # 1. Veining & Silica Flooding – Strongly Hemlo-Like Hemlo deposits are famous for: * Thick quartz–carbonate veins * Multi-generation silica flooding * Transposed and sheared vein networks The FCM core exhibits: * Long, continuous, strongly developed quartz–carbonate veins * Multiple overprinting events, including late-stage brecciation * Sustained silica flooding over tens of metres These are hallmark structural and hydrothermal features of Hemlo-style mineralisation. Verdict: ✔ *Veining architecture is directly comparable to Hemlo’s gold-bearing vein systems.* --- #  2. Presence of Coarse Sulphides – A Major Hemlo Analogy Hemlo gold is intimately associated with: * Pyrite (fine to coarse) * Molybdenite in streaks and blebs * Local chalcopyrite and sphalerite * Sulphide-rich selvages around quartz–carbonate veins The updated information — coarse sulphides throughout the FCM interval — is highly significant. FCM core shows: * Thick coarse sulphide bands and clusters * Strong sulphide–silica association * Sulphides concentrated along high-strain planes * Disseminated sulphides within altered host rocks This level and grain size of sulphidation is far more characteristic of productive zones within the Hemlo system than initially assumed. Verdict: ✔ *Coarse sulphides dramatically increase the similarity to Hemlo’s gold-bearing horizons.* ✔ *This is no longer “upper, weakly sulphidic Hemlo-style” — this moves into the range of potentially fertile mineralised corridors.* --- #  3. Structural Preparation – Classic Hemlo-Style Shear Zone Geology Hemlo gold occurs in polyphase ductile shear zones, producing: * Mylonitic fabrics * Sheared porphyry and basalt * Repeated deformation of silica veins The FCM core displays: * High-strain fabrics throughout the interval * Shear banding cutting major veins * Quartz–carbonate lenses dragged into the foliation * Sulphides aligned along deformation planes These are textbook ingredients for Archean lode gold mineralisation and match Hemlo’s structural style extremely well. Verdict: ✔ *The deformation intensity and geometry are strikingly consistent with Hemlo's ore-hosting shear sequences.* --- #  4. Alteration – Consistent With Hemlo’s Hydrothermal Signature Typical Hemlo alteration includes: * Silica–carbonate flooding * Sericite–silica halos * Hematite streaking in places * Feldspar destructive alteration FCM core shows * Pervasive silica–carbonate alteration * Pale alteration envelopes around veins * Local sericitic textures * Strong correlati

data.author: char71
data.content: Https://x.com/i/status/1999502055937884464 Market Summary > @FirstClassMetal LON: #FCM 2.20 GBX+0.50 (29.41%) up past 5 days 12 Dec, 15:09 GMT • 2026 Around 200 core samples have been dispatched for assay, with several logged intersections displaying visually encouraging geological features that support the decision to continue drilling. What the Core Looks Like The core is dark, fine-grained, and strongly banded, with: Well-developed foliation (the streaky, planar fabric running along the core) Alternating light and dark bands Some brittle fracturing but no obvious thick quartz veining Patchy silica flooding and lighter bleached sections Thin red pencil lines marking meterage, not mineralization This is very typical of Hemlo-style host rocks, which are famously highly deformed, silicified, and sericite–rich volcanic and sedimentary units. What Rock Type This Most Likely Is The core strongly resembles: Hemlo Sericite–Silica Schist (the classic Hemlo host lithology) Characterised by: Dark grey to black colour Strong planar foliation Silica flooding Often pyrite-bearing (though it may be very fine and not visible in a photo) At Hemlo, gold occurs almost entirely within sericite–silica altered schists, not big quartz veins. So this type of rock is considered favourable host rock. What the Textures Mean 1. Strong Foliation / Banding Indicates: High degree of deformation Shear zone or structural corridor Exactly the environments where Hemlo-style gold deposits form 2. Bleached or Light Bands These light zones represent: Silicification Sericite alteration Both are key alteration signatures at the Hemlo deposit. 3. Dark Massive Zones Likely: More mafic volcanics or sediment-derived units Less altered but still within the deformation zone 4. Fractured Core Normal for competent silica-rich rocks; not an indicator of mineralization by itself. Is There Visible Gold or Sulphide in the Photo? No visible gold or obvious coarse sulphides appear in this image. That is not surprising — Hemlo gold is notoriously “invisible”, locked within extremely fine-grained sulphide or alteration minerals. Even high-grade Hemlo ore often shows: No quartz veining No visible gold Very fine pyrite or arsenopyrite only detectable under a microscope So lack of visible sulphides ≠ lack of gold potential. Does This Look Like Good Core? For North Hemlo? Yes — it is promising host rock. Why: Strong deformation Silica–sericite alteration Classic Hemlo-style stratigraphy Hemlo mineralization does not require quartz veins or obvious sulphides This is the type of rock you want to see before assays come back. What This Core Suggests About FCM’s Target This interval appears to lie in: A deformation zone Within altered volcanic/sedimentary units similar to those at the Hemlo deposit Potentially in the right structural

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Interesting to see that new neighbours Hemlo Mining Corporation are continuing to bolster its Senior Leadership Team. Firstly, Garett Macdonald has been appointed Vice President Operations, and will also assume responsibilities of General Manager at the Hemlo Mine, supported by Deputy General Manager Dennis Bigras. In this role, Mr. Macdonald will report to Eric Tremblay, Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Macdonald is a professional mining engineer with over 30 years of industry experience in mine operations, project development and corporate leadership. In addition, Perry Blanchard has been appointed Vice President of Sustainability, bringing nearly 30 years of experience in environment, health and safety management in the mining industry. Most recently, Mr. Blanchard served as Vice President, Environment and Sustainability at Maritime Resources Corp., where he led the Hammerdown Project through environmental assessment, permitting, construction transition, and ultimately acquisition by New Found Gold Corp. in November 2025. It is clear that HMC mean business as it looks to establish itself as a leading Canadian mid-tier growth-focused gold producer, with an immediate focus on maximizing the value of the Hemlo Gold Mine's existing infrastructure through a fit-for-purpose operating approach, while unlocking new opportunities through “aggressive brownfields exploration.” There is little doubt in my mind that HMC is a very ambitious new company who do not intend simply sitting back and draining the vestiges of gold from the old Hemlo pit. They are exploring neighbouring areas, and so will be watching the activities of First Class Metals like a hawk. The results of our maiden scout drill programme on the DOT will be very much on their radar. It would be good to know if MS or JK have touched base with them yet. A Zoom chat over a cuppa and a Custard Cream would do no harm. Good assays and our timing akin to this news, as well as continued pog increases, could be absolutely perfect.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: This is simply to do with transparency rules under the takeover code which requires notification of holdings above 1 per cent. This is done through the submission of Form 8.3. General market rules require notification when holdings exceed 3 per cent. Notification is then x TR1 which I suspect is where the confusion is coming. Form 8.3’s do not show increases or reductions in holdings as do TR1’s from time to time. 8.3’s simply show what is held at the time of the requirement if you are over one per cent.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Fcm don’t appear to have confirmed what additional meterage has been drilled over and above the planned 700m. As such, and as risk factors would come very much into play in a ‘first pass’, I would argue not more than between 50 to 100m. A 10 hole average at best therefore would give us around 75 to 80 metres actual length for each, with true depth obviously less with  how much so depending on angle of entry (variously -70 to -45 ). A 80m hole at -70 entry for example would give true depth of X = 80 x sine 70 which is 80 x 0.9397 for 75.18 m. The same meterage of 80 but at -45 would give a shallower 55.57m. Both are decent depths for a ‘near surface’ maiden drill programme.

Early holes #1, #2 , #3 and #4 were drilled in the vicinity of the 19.6 g/t outcrop sample, with #5 and #6 adjacent to the south east corner of Dead Otter Lake some 2 km’s distant. data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Drilling restarted last week after a temporary cessation just after NH_25_09. In the RNS (now 11 days ago) Fcm confirmed that the intention was to recommence drilling last week to complete the planned programme before Christmas. We know already that they were talking about ‘surpassing’ the planned meterage (700m). They should be pretty much finished in the next day or two if not already? Fcm confirmed that “ the geological features observed to date reinforce our confidence in the Dead Otter trend as a compelling gold target within the North Hemlo Project. We look forward to receiving the first assay results in the New Year”. So, whilst no assays yet (200 samples have already gone to Actlabs), the team are clearly liking what they see in the core. The terminology used suggests a pretty high degree of confidence in what the lab analysis might show. In addition, although this is a pilot or ‘first pass’ drill programme, I am especially pleased to see that they have the confidence to exceed the meterage before any assays are received confirming that they are positive for au. Again, this tends to reaffirm that high degree of confidence, as dd drilling at even near surface is a costly exercise especially in the relatively high risk world of a first or maiden drill programme on a project area. Can’t wait for first results.

data.author: Big_kahuna
data.content: There is no takeover bid for First Class Metals. Administrators control ~33.5% of the shares and intend to dispose of that stake, likely via a block sale or strategic placement. Any sale would typically be done at a modest premium to market rather than at takeover levels. If priced sensibly, a block sale should not dilute existing shareholders and can be positive if it brings a funded, long-term holder. A full takeover would only become realistic after drilling success and a maiden resource. At this stage, this is structural positioning, not a bid.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Interesting to see that new neighbours Hemlo Mining Corporation are continuing to bolster its Senior Leadership Team. Firstly, Garett Macdonald has been appointed Vice President Operations, and will also assume responsibilities of General Manager at the Hemlo Mine, supported by Deputy General Manager Dennis Bigras. In this role, Mr. Macdonald will report to Eric Tremblay, Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Macdonald is a professional mining engineer with over 30 years of industry experience in mine operations, project development and corporate leadership. In addition, Perry Blanchard has been appointed Vice President of Sustainability, bringing nearly 30 years of experience in environment, health and safety management in the mining industry. Most recently, Mr. Blanchard served as Vice President, Environment and Sustainability at Maritime Resources Corp., where he led the Hammerdown Project through environmental assessment, permitting, construction transition, and ultimately acquisition by New Found Gold Corp. in November 2025. It is clear that HMC mean business as it looks to establish itself as a leading Canadian mid-tier growth-focused gold producer, with an immediate focus on maximizing the value of the Hemlo Gold Mine's existing infrastructure through a fit-for-purpose operating approach, while unlocking new opportunities through “aggressive brownfields exploration.” There is little doubt in my mind that HMC is a very ambitious new company who do not intend simply sitting back and draining the vestiges of gold from the old Hemlo pit. They are exploring neighbouring areas, and so will be watching the activities of First Class Metals like a hawk. The results of our maiden scout drill programme on the DOT will be very much on their radar. It would be good to know if MS or JK have touched base with them yet. A Zoom chat over a cuppa and a Custard Cream would do no harm. Good assays and our timing akin to this news, as well as continued pog increases, could be absolutely perfect.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: This is simply to do with transparency rules under the takeover code which requires notification of holdings above 1 per cent. This is done through the submission of Form 8.3. General market rules require notification when holdings exceed 3 per cent. Notification is then x TR1 which I suspect is where the confusion is coming. Form 8.3’s do not show increases or reductions in holdings as do TR1’s from time to time. 8.3’s simply show what is held at the time of the requirement if you are over one per cent.

Background
First Class Metals listed on the LSE in July 2022 and is focused on metals exploration in Ontario, Canada which has a robust and thriving junior mineral exploration sector. In particular, the Hemlo 'camp' near Marathon, Ontario is a proven world class address for gold exploration, featuring the Hemlo gold deposit operated by Barrick Mining (>23M oz gold produced), with the past producing Geco and Winston Lake base metal deposits also situated in the region.
FCM currently holds 100% ownership of seven claim blocks covering over 250km² in northwest Ontario. A further three blocks are under option and cover an additional 30km2.FCM is focussed on exploring for gold but has base metals and critical metals mineralisation. FCM is maintaining a joint venture with GT Resources on the West Pickle Lake Property a drill-proven ultra-high-grade Ni-Cu project.
The flagship properties, North Hemlo and Sunbeam, are gold focussed. North Hemlo has a significant discovery in the Dead Otter trend which is a discontinuous 3.5km gold anomalous trend with a 19.6g/t Au peak grab sample. This sampling being the highest known assay from a grab sample ever recorded on the North Limb of Hemlo.
In October 2022 FCM completed the option to purchase the historical high-grade past-producing Sunbeam gold mine near Atikokan, Ontario, ~15 km southeast of Agnico Eagle's Hammond Reef gold deposit (3.3 Moz of open pit probable gold reserves).
FCM acquired the Zigzag Project near Armstrong, Ontario in March 2023. The property features Li-Ta-bearing pegmatites in the same belt as Green Technology Metals' Seymour Lake Project, which contains a Mineral Resource estimate of 9.9 Mt @ 1.04% Li2O. Zigzag was successfully drilled prior to Christmas 2023 and results have now been released.
The Kerrs Gold property, acquired under option by First Class Metals in April 2024, is located in northeastern Ontario within the Abitibi Greenstone Belt, one of the world's most prolific gold-producing regions. The project holds a historical inferred resource of approximately 386,000 ounces of gold, underscoring its potential as a meaningful addition to FCM's expanding gold portfolio. Kerrs Gold complements the Company's exploration strategy and provides exposure to a well-established mining district. FCM is currently reviewing plans to advance the project and further unlock its value.
The significant potential of the properties for precious, base and battery metals relates to 'nearology', since all properties lie in the same districts as known deposits (Hemlo, Hammond Reef, Seymour Lake), and either contain known showings, geochemical or geophysical anomalies, or favourable structures along strike from known showings (e.g. the Esa project, with an inferred Hemlo-style shear along strike from known gold occurrences).

The information contained within this announcement is deemed to constitute inside information as stipulated under the retained EU law version of the Market Abuse Regulation (EU) No. 596/2014 (the "UK MAR") which is part of UK law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018. The information is disclosed in accordance with the Company's obligations under Article 17 of the UK MAR. Upon the publication of this announcement, this inside information is now considered to be in the public domain.
FIRST CLASS METALS PLC
30 January 2026
Funding & Corporate Update
First Class Metals PLC (
"First Class Metals", "FCM"
or the
"Company"
), the UK-listed exploration company advancing high-grade, district-scale gold opportunities in Ontario, Canada, is pleased to announce that it has entered into a new interest-free Convertible Loan Note Instrument (
"CLN"
or the
"Convertible Loan Notes"
) with an international investor (the
"Investor"
) for up to £1,000,000.
Highlights and Funding Overview
·
The Company has secured funding in order to advance its maiden drill programme on the Sunbeam Property and general working capital requirements.
·
Under the terms of the CLN, the Investor has agreed to subscribe for up to £1.0 million interest-free convertible loan notes of £1 each, to be issued in tranches, with a twelve-month maturity from the date of the instrument.
·
The first tranche of £350,000 has been agreed and is expected to be drawn shortly, with further tranches available in accordance with the terms of the CLN.
·
The Convertible Loan Notes are interest-free and are convertible at the option of the Investor at a price equal to 82% of the lowest daily VWAP over the five trading days immediately prior to the submission of a conversion notice. Conversion of any outstanding balance is mandatory at maturity, subject to statutory shareholding limits.
·
The Company retains the right, prior to maturity, to redeem the Convertible Loan Notes at 125% of their nominal value.
·
A 2% commitment fee is payable in respect of each tranche and may be offset against the subscription proceeds at drawdown.
·
The CLN additionally provides the Investor with warrants for each tranche equalling to 35% of the convertible loan notes comprising that tranche (with a maximum of 350,000 warrants for the 1,000,000 loan notes). The subscription price for each warrant is 120% of the closing price of an ordinary share on the business day immediately preceding the day of the subscription of the tranche. The warrants will be exercisable at any time within three years from the date of grant.
·
In connection with the subscription of the first tranche, the Company will issue 4,803,922 warrants exercisable at 2.55 pence per share.
·
Payment of final CAD$ 100,000 due to the Kerrs Gold property option holders to be made in order to acquire a 100% ownership of the Property.
Use of Proceeds & Corporate Update
The proceeds of the Convertible Loan Notes will be used to initiate a drill programme at the Company's Sunbeam Property in Ontario, Canada and provide for general working capital requirements.
Operationally, the location of the initial drill targets at Sunbeam requires hard-frozen ground conditions to ensure safe and effective access. These conditions are now present during the Ontario winter season, enabling the Company to advance drilling. A drill programme is currently being designed, and the Company will provide further updates on rig mobilisation and programme timing.
In addition, the Company is accelerating the final cash consideration of CAD$100,000 payable to the option holders of the Kerrs Gold Property. Upon completion of this payment, First Class Metals will hold a 100% ownership interest in the Kerrs Gold Property, which hosts a historical resource of approximately 386,000 ounces of gold.
James Knowles, Executive Chairman, commented:
"This funding agreement is a deliberate and strategic step to ensure First Class Metals is fully capitalised to act decisively at a critical point in our operational calendar. The ability to advance programmes at the right time is fundamental to maximising value in an exploration-led business. Given the well-publicised move higher in gold prices to new all-time highs in the last few months, we believe now is the time to progress our portfolio on multiple fronts.
At the same time, the Company is completing the final steps to secure full ownership of the Kerrs Gold Property, a substantial gold asset with a defined 386,000-ounce gold resource. The Company felt this to be a prudent step considering market factors and ensuring the Company has the flexibility to make quick decisions in relation to the Property."
For Further Information:
Engage with us by asking questions, watching video summaries, and seeing what other shareholders have to say.
Navigate to our Interactive Investor hub here

https://firstclassmetalsplc.com

data.author: pkwendall
data.content: ✔ Mitigating Factors* •⁠  ⁠FCM can *redeem at 125%* to prevent conversion if the share price is under pressure. •⁠  ⁠Tranches are *not automatic* — the company can control the pace of drawdown. •⁠  ⁠If drilling success lifts the share price, dilution becomes less impactful. Strategic Interpretation* This is a *bridge-style financing* designed to get FCM through a critical operational window. The company is clearly betting that: •⁠  ⁠Drilling at Sunbeam will create value. •⁠  ⁠Gold’s strong price environment will support investor sentiment. •⁠  ⁠Full ownership of Kerrs Gold will strengthen the long-term portfolio. The structure is not unusual for AIM/TSX-V style explorers, but it does require the company to deliver operational progress to offset dilution risk.

data.author: pkwendall
data.content: Breakdown of today's RNS — focusing on what actually matters for funding, dilution risk, and operational progress. **Summary of the Funding & Corporate Update** 1. New £1,000,000 Convertible Loan Note (CLN) Facility** FCM has secured an interest‑free CLN agreement with an international investor, providing up to **£1m** in staged tranches. **Key terms:** - **Interest‑free** (unusual and favourable on the surface). - **First tranche: £350,000**, expected to be drawn shortly. - **Conversion price:** - 82% of the **lowest daily VWAP** over the **5 days** before conversion. - This is a *variable‑price convertible* — often called a “death spiral” structure if mismanaged. - **Mandatory conversion at maturity** (12 months), unless redeemed earlier. - **Company buy‑back option:** - FCM can redeem notes at **125%** of nominal value before maturity. - **Commitment fee:** 2% per tranche. - **Warrants:** - 35% of each tranche value. - Up to **350,000 warrants** total. - Strike price = 120% of the closing price before each tranche. - 3‑year life. - **First tranche warrants:** - **4,803,922 warrants @ 2.55p**. 2. Use of Proceeds** - Fund **maiden drill programme** at the **Sunbeam Property** (Ontario). - Provide **general working capital**. - Pay the final **CAD$100,000** to secure **100% ownership** of the **Kerrs Gold Property** (386,000 oz historical resource). 3. Operational Update** - Winter conditions now allow access to drill targets at Sunbeam. - Drill programme design underway; mobilisation updates to follow. - Kerrs Gold final payment will complete full ownership. --- 📊 **What This Means for Shareholders** *✔ Positive Aspects** - Funding secured without traditional interest costs. - Enables drilling at a strategically important time (high gold prices). - Full ownership of Kerrs Gold strengthens the asset base. - Warrants priced at a premium (120%) — better than discounted warrants. *⚠ Dilution & Risk Considerations** This CLN is **highly dilutive** if converted: - Conversion at **82% of the lowest VWAP** is a *discounted variable‑price mechanism*. - If the share price weakens, conversion creates more shares → more dilution → further price pressure. - The 4.8m warrants at 2.55p add additional potential dilution. This structure is common for small-cap explorers but requires careful management to avoid a downward spiral.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Our neighbours have just released yet another “RNS”, (Canadian equivalent that is ) today. The headline is :- “The Company (Hemlo Mining Corp.) has initiated an aggressive 130,000 metre exploration drilling program aimed at extending mine life, de-risking the near-term mine plan and identifying near-mine growth opportunities. The 2026 exploration drilling program is expected to serve as the foundation for an updated technical report, expected H2 2027.” 130 kilometres of drilling; 130 km’s !!!!!! Both infill to upgrade category, and also growth (Stepout). That is one hell of a programme. And one hell of a lot of money. If we have hit gold at decent grades, I am positive that HMC will be looking very very closely at Fcm and North Hemlo.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Our new neighbours at Hemlo have released positive results of a section of their 2025 E Zone drilling campaign. The E Zone is located near surface and is close to existing underground development. HMC drilled a total of  6 holes for 4,240 metres. This, they say, proves categorically that new mineralised zones remain to be discovered in the mine area. Decent intervals and grades of up to a magnificent 90.45 g/t which is the stuff dreams are made of. If assays from our maiden drill programme conducted just a handful of kilometres away, and due imminently, look anything like these, then First Class Metals are off to the races:- Hole 6702501 intersected 19.11 g/t Au over 5.0 m Hole 6702503 intersected 15.79 g/t Au over 5.0 m Hole 6702505 intersected 7.08 g/t Au over 12.1 m and 90.45 g/t Au over 2.6 m

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Fcm don’t appear to have confirmed what additional meterage has been drilled over and above the planned 700m. As such, and as risk factors would come very much into play in a ‘first pass’, I would argue not more than between 50 to 100m. A 10 hole average at best therefore would give us around 75 to 80 metres actual length for each, with true depth obviously less with  how much so depending on angle of entry (variously -70 to -45 ). A 80m hole at -70 entry for example would give true depth of X = 80 x sine 70 which is 80 x 0.9397 for 75.18 m. The same meterage of 80 but at -45 would give a shallower 55.57m. Both are decent depths for a ‘near surface’ maiden drill programme.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Charting confirms that Fcm have drilled along trend from East to West. Early holes #1, #2 , #3 and #4 were drilled in the vicinity of the 19.6 g/t outcrop sample, with #5 and #6 adjacent to the south east corner of Dead Otter Lake some 2 km’s distant. The final #7 to #10 have been drilled around the Dead Otter Showing at 3.1 g/t to the south of the western side of DOL. This means that they have drilled a linear length of circa 3.5 km’s on a sub 1000m pilot drill programme! That’s a great result in itself! ……..and EVERY drill core shows potential mineralisation! The potential at North Hemlo could be very significant. Pity they couldn’t have sneaked just one cheeky assay out of Actlabs pre Christmas!!

data.content: Apols, Should read core prospective for gold; not positive. I do wish there was an edit function on Lse.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Drilling restarted last week after a temporary cessation just after NH_25_09. In the RNS (now 11 days ago) Fcm confirmed that the intention was to recommence drilling last week to complete the planned programme before Christmas. We know already that they were talking about ‘surpassing’ the planned meterage (700m). They should be pretty much finished in the next day or two if not already? Fcm confirmed that “ the geological features observed to date reinforce our confidence in the Dead Otter trend as a compelling gold target within the North Hemlo Project. We look forward to receiving the first assay results in the New Year”. So, whilst no assays yet (200 samples have already gone to Actlabs), the team are clearly liking what they see in the core. The terminology used suggests a pretty high degree of confidence in what the lab analysis might show. In addition, although this is a pilot or ‘first pass’ drill programme, I am especially pleased to see that they have the confidence to exceed the meterage before any assays are received confirming that they are positive for au. Again, this tends to reaffirm that high degree of confidence, as dd drilling at even near surface is a costly exercise especially in the relatively high risk world of a first or maiden drill programme on a project area. Can’t wait for first results.

data.author: Big_kahuna
data.content: There is no takeover bid for First Class Metals. Administrators control ~33.5% of the shares and intend to dispose of that stake, likely via a block sale or strategic placement. Any sale would typically be done at a modest premium to market rather than at takeover levels. If priced sensibly, a block sale should not dilute existing shareholders and can be positive if it brings a funded, long-term holder. A full takeover would only become realistic after drilling success and a maiden resource. At this stage, this is structural positioning, not a bid.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Great to see today’s report that our new neighbours, Hemlo Mining Corp. (TSXV: HMMC) a new mid-tier Canadian gold producer, have announced the successful completion of its first gold pour at the Hemlo Gold Mine since acquiring the operation from Barrick Mining Corp. on November 26, 2025. This inaugural pour produced approximately 6,704 ounces of gold, underscoring the continuity and resilience of mining and processing operations through the ownership transition. Plant performance, throughput, and metallurgical recoveries remain fully aligned with the Company's operating plan.   Jason Kosec, President and CEO of Hemlo Mining Corp., stated: "The first gold pour under Hemlo Mining Corp. marks a defining milestone for our Company. Against a record gold-price environment, our team executed a seamless operational transition while maintaining an uncompromising focus on health, safety, and the environment. This pour reflects the strength of our mine, the quality of our people, and the disciplined plan we are now putting into action to stabilize operations, drive performance, and unlock meaningful long-term value."   Since closing the acquisition, the Company has advanced a focused integration program emphasizing operational discipline, environmental stewardship, and a reinforced safety culture across the site. Hemlo Mining Corp. is committed to establishing Hemlo as a high-performing, responsibly-operated Canadian gold mine with…………… substantial growth potential! They will certainly be keeping a close eye on Fist Class Metals North Hemlo exploration!

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Further to The Sunday Roast interview, we really have to consider the potential outcomes for Fcm just now. Zig Zag….Spodumene up again overnight to $1320. That’s a rise of over 100 per cent in the last few months. Li shortfall now predicted for 2026 rather than 2028. Second Li trend confirmed and third suspected. ZZ could very well come back into play a lot sooner than expected. The asset sale and tokenisation LOI’s were confirmed in i/v as still very much in play. A successful outcome for either of these would be superb; both would blow the doors off! North Hemlo drilling has restarted. From what we can see, most if not all, of the holes drilled so far appear very promising. A quick scan of the trend map shoes that there must be almost 3 and a half kilometres between NH-25-01 and 02 to the east, and NH-25-06 to the west. If both extremes shows gold in assay then there is the potential for a gold strike length of at least that length. This would be way bigger in linear distance than the Hemlo Gold mine now belonging to the newly created Hemlo Mining Corporation who will, I have no doubt, be all over our NH activities like a rash. This could be absolutely huge! And then Sunbeam. District scale potential and results due but not even scratched the surface. LOI success and you can bet MS will be hitting SB with everything he can! Excitement definitely returning here.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Interesting to see that new neighbours Hemlo Mining Corporation are continuing to bolster its Senior Leadership Team. Firstly, Garett Macdonald has been appointed Vice President Operations, and will also assume responsibilities of General Manager at the Hemlo Mine, supported by Deputy General Manager Dennis Bigras. In this role, Mr. Macdonald will report to Eric Tremblay, Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Macdonald is a professional mining engineer with over 30 years of industry experience in mine operations, project development and corporate leadership. In addition, Perry Blanchard has been appointed Vice President of Sustainability, bringing nearly 30 years of experience in environment, health and safety management in the mining industry. Most recently, Mr. Blanchard served as Vice President, Environment and Sustainability at Maritime Resources Corp., where he led the Hammerdown Project through environmental assessment, permitting, construction transition, and ultimately acquisition by New Found Gold Corp. in November 2025. It is clear that HMC mean business as it looks to establish itself as a leading Canadian mid-tier growth-focused gold producer, with an immediate focus on maximizing the value of the Hemlo Gold Mine's existing infrastructure through a fit-for-purpose operating approach, while unlocking new opportunities through “aggressive brownfields exploration.” There is little doubt in my mind that HMC is a very ambitious new company who do not intend simply sitting back and draining the vestiges of gold from the old Hemlo pit. They are exploring neighbouring areas, and so will be watching the activities of First Class Metals like a hawk. The results of our maiden scout drill programme on the DOT will be very much on their radar. It would be good to know if MS or JK have touched base with them yet. A Zoom chat over a cuppa and a Custard Cream would do no harm. Good assays and our timing akin to this news, as well as continued pog increases, could be absolutely perfect.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: This is simply to do with transparency rules under the takeover code which requires notification of holdings above 1 per cent. This is done through the submission of Form 8.3. General market rules require notification when holdings exceed 3 per cent. Notification is then x TR1 which I suspect is where the confusion is coming. Form 8.3’s do not show increases or reductions in holdings as do TR1’s from time to time. 8.3’s simply show what is held at the time of the requirement if you are over one per cent.

data.author: char71
data.content: 𝗙𝗖𝗠 - 𝗡𝗢𝗥𝗧𝗛 𝗛𝗘𝗠𝗟𝗢 𝗨𝗣𝗗𝗔𝗧𝗘 First Class Metals has successfully completed its maiden drill programme at the North Hemlo Gold Project, delivering exactly what early-stage exploration should: scale, continuity and geological confirmation. Programme highlights 10 diamond drill holes completed ~3km of strike tested along the Dead Otter trend Drilling exceeded contracted metres Visually prospective geology in every hole Deformation, quartz veining & sulphides consistent with a Hemlo-style gold system 300+ samples already dispatched for assay Location matters North Hemlo sits in the world-class Hemlo Greenstone Belt (>23Moz Au produced). With Barrick’s US$1.09bn exit from Hemlo completed earlier this month, the district is firmly back in focus — and FCM’s Dead Otter trend lies directly alongside the new operator’s ground. Multiple gold styles remain in play, including: • Shear-hosted orogenic gold • Structurally controlled mineralisation at greenstone–granite contacts Assays will determine grade, but geology underpins value — and the geological evidence supports continued confidence in the Dead Otter trend. #FCM https://firstclassmetalsplc.com/announcements/7318908 https://x.com/i/status/2003370543559397745

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: The below is a confirmation of the situation from July RNS. We know from interview with MS that we are waiting on LiDAR dataset review. Clearly Fcm are wanting to be in a position to report on the Sunbeam position in its entirety which makes sense. Also note that the OJEP grant app had been submitted by July with a focus on the Roy trend. · Extensive soil sampling programme completedOver 500 A-horizon samples collected across 4km of the Roy structure - now in the laboratory, targeting gold-in-soil anomalies along this key trend. · Very Low Frequency ("VLF")-magnetic survey192 stations across 3.8km of grid surveyed; data undergoing interpretation to refine targets ahead of possible drill planning. · Historic shafts located and sampledProspecting rediscovered the 113 feet deep B43 shaft, with grab samples showing visible chalcopyrite and galena. B45 not yet located. · Roy structural review suggests Hammond Reef-style potentialStructural report by Prof. M.L. Hill confirms key controls on Roy trend; further petrology and core review recommended. · LiDAR dataset under expert reviewThird-party consultants are interpreting terrain data to sharpen structural models across the broader corridor. · 2025 Ontario Junior Explorers Programmes ("OJEP") grant application submittedFourth consecutive year FCM has applied - this time focused on advancing the Roy zone following encouraging field results.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Perhaps so. It’s certainly going to be the start of a news rich period for Fcm: 79th Group shares potential buyer, asset sale, tokenisation of asset, 2025 Sunbeam fieldwork results (and hopefully release of plans at Sunbeam for 2026), and results of maiden drill programme for gold at North Hemlo. Also in the mix is the question of Zig Zag after another 14.6 per cent rise in the price of Lithium last week, and, of course, what could happen if NH results are good. Our new neighbour will be watching out for those like a hawk.

data.author: pkwendall
data.content: This is key.. Tranches are not automatic — the company can control the pace of drawdown. Hopefully if the planned asset sale happens in time, there should be no need for FCM to draw-down the 2nd and 3rd tranches 🤞🏼

data.author: pkwendall
data.content: ✔ Mitigating Factors* •⁠  ⁠FCM can *redeem at 125%* to prevent conversion if the share price is under pressure. •⁠  ⁠Tranches are *not automatic* — the company can control the pace of drawdown. •⁠  ⁠If drilling success lifts the share price, dilution becomes less impactful. Strategic Interpretation* This is a *bridge-style financing* designed to get FCM through a critical operational window. The company is clearly betting that: •⁠  ⁠Drilling at Sunbeam will create value. •⁠  ⁠Gold’s strong price environment will support investor sentiment. •⁠  ⁠Full ownership of Kerrs Gold will strengthen the long-term portfolio. The structure is not unusual for AIM/TSX-V style explorers, but it does require the company to deliver operational progress to offset dilution risk.

data.author: pkwendall
data.content: Breakdown of today's RNS — focusing on what actually matters for funding, dilution risk, and operational progress. **Summary of the Funding & Corporate Update** 1. New £1,000,000 Convertible Loan Note (CLN) Facility** FCM has secured an interest‑free CLN agreement with an international investor, providing up to **£1m** in staged tranches. **Key terms:** - **Interest‑free** (unusual and favourable on the surface). - **First tranche: £350,000**, expected to be drawn shortly. - **Conversion price:** - 82% of the **lowest daily VWAP** over the **5 days** before conversion. - This is a *variable‑price convertible* — often called a “death spiral” structure if mismanaged. - **Mandatory conversion at maturity** (12 months), unless redeemed earlier. - **Company buy‑back option:** - FCM can redeem notes at **125%** of nominal value before maturity. - **Commitment fee:** 2% per tranche. - **Warrants:** - 35% of each tranche value. - Up to **350,000 warrants** total. - Strike price = 120% of the closing price before each tranche. - 3‑year life. - **First tranche warrants:** - **4,803,922 warrants @ 2.55p**. 2. Use of Proceeds** - Fund **maiden drill programme** at the **Sunbeam Property** (Ontario). - Provide **general working capital**. - Pay the final **CAD$100,000** to secure **100% ownership** of the **Kerrs Gold Property** (386,000 oz historical resource). 3. Operational Update** - Winter conditions now allow access to drill targets at Sunbeam. - Drill programme design underway; mobilisation updates to follow. - Kerrs Gold final payment will complete full ownership. --- 📊 **What This Means for Shareholders** *✔ Positive Aspects** - Funding secured without traditional interest costs. - Enables drilling at a strategically important time (high gold prices). - Full ownership of Kerrs Gold strengthens the asset base. - Warrants priced at a premium (120%) — better than discounted warrants. *⚠ Dilution & Risk Considerations** This CLN is **highly dilutive** if converted: - Conversion at **82% of the lowest VWAP** is a *discounted variable‑price mechanism*. - If the share price weakens, conversion creates more shares → more dilution → further price pressure. - The 4.8m warrants at 2.55p add additional potential dilution. This structure is common for small-cap explorers but requires careful management to avoid a downward spiral.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Our neighbours have just released yet another “RNS”, (Canadian equivalent that is ) today. The headline is :- “The Company (Hemlo Mining Corp.) has initiated an aggressive 130,000 metre exploration drilling program aimed at extending mine life, de-risking the near-term mine plan and identifying near-mine growth opportunities. The 2026 exploration drilling program is expected to serve as the foundation for an updated technical report, expected H2 2027.” 130 kilometres of drilling; 130 km’s !!!!!! Both infill to upgrade category, and also growth (Stepout). That is one hell of a programme. And one hell of a lot of money. If we have hit gold at decent grades, I am positive that HMC will be looking very very closely at Fcm and North Hemlo.
data.thread_title: Jeeeeeeesus! 130 kilometres of drilling by neighbour

data.author: Crossthetea

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Ian, Course it can. Think about it. Initials were submitted just before December 10th. Subsequents followed on 23rd or Christmas Eve. Then the festive and NY hols. Then a further (just) 4 weeks to now. And this is the busy time for the laboratories in any event. I would say we could get results pretty imminently in exploration terms. Early February would be excellent, but  It depends on whether Fcm release piecemeal, or the full hit.

data.author: ianrpbertpaterso
data.content: Anyone got any idea when we can expect assay results? Feels like we should be getting news by now. Can't take this long for preliminary results.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Our new neighbours at Hemlo have released positive results of a section of their 2025 E Zone drilling campaign. The E Zone is located near surface and is close to existing underground development. HMC drilled a total of  6 holes for 4,240 metres. This, they say, proves categorically that new mineralised zones remain to be discovered in the mine area. Decent intervals and grades of up to a magnificent 90.45 g/t which is the stuff dreams are made of. If assays from our maiden drill programme conducted just a handful of kilometres away, and due imminently, look anything like these, then First Class Metals are off to the races:- Hole 6702501 intersected 19.11 g/t Au over 5.0 m Hole 6702503 intersected 15.79 g/t Au over 5.0 m Hole 6702505 intersected 7.08 g/t Au over 12.1 m and 90.45 g/t Au over 2.6 m

Whilst we wait anxiously for confirmation of gold in assay from North Hemlo core, I checked back on previous assays from NH grabs for silver….? “Furthermore, the prospecting in the vicinity of the stripped area reported a 0.5ppm (0.5g/t) in a grab sample 30 metres north of the 2.3pppm showing / stripped area and also reported up to 0.43% copper, whilst a second sample anomalous in gold reported 7g/t Ag (Silver) and 0.33% Cu.” (From Dead Otter update 20 Jan 25).

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: 1. Spodumene. Another lift overnight for a rise of $50 to $1490 [3.47%]. Ever better for Zig Zag as Lithium price rises opens door for second trend drilling OR asset sale interest! 2. LOI asset sale. Asset not confirmed but my money on Kerrs as likely favourite with NI43-101 gold resource. News due January. Funding for further NH expo, and for SB, would be secured when disposal successfully completed. 3. Asset tokenisation LOI also still ongoing. News due January. 4. Sunbeam 2025 exploration programme results must be due imminently as LiDAR dataset review has to near completion. Results could confirm ‘district scale’ gold potential and nail down a 2026 drill programme. 5. AND…….North Hemlo pilot drill programme now completed. Core looking prospective for gold from ALL 10 holes😎 Initial 200 samples were dispatched to Actlabs just before 10 Dec whilst remaining new samples were being prepped right up to the 24th. Initial assays expected January and could confirm a new GOLD DISCOVERY. Other than that,  nothing to see here! 😁
data.thread_title: Boxing Day and the clock ticks….

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: DaP, Oh I know 😂😂 but suppose it had been official. A bit of overtime for Arnold doing a sneaky one sample assay and a pre festive RNS confirmation of gold in core. We need a bit of ‘Good Cheer’ generally I think. But it’s looking rather promising.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Fcm don’t appear to have confirmed what additional meterage has been drilled over and above the planned 700m. As such, and as risk factors would come very much into play in a ‘first pass’, I would argue not more than between 50 to 100m. A 10 hole average at best therefore would give us around 75 to 80 metres actual length for each, with true depth obviously less with  how much so depending on angle of entry (variously -70 to -45 ). A 80m hole at -70 entry for example would give true depth of X = 80 x sine 70 which is 80 x 0.9397 for 75.18 m. The same meterage of 80 but at -45 would give a shallower 55.57m. Both are decent depths for a ‘near surface’ maiden drill programme.

data.author: Sunningdale1
data.content: Maiden drilling programme successfully completed at North Hemlo. Ten diamond drill holes completed sat Dead Otter over 3km testing multiple priority targets https://x.com/Brand_UK/status/2003366622740840725

data.author: DaProphet

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Charting confirms that Fcm have drilled along trend from East to West. Early holes #1, #2 , #3 and #4 were drilled in the vicinity of the 19.6 g/t outcrop sample, with #5 and #6 adjacent to the south east corner of Dead Otter Lake some 2 km’s distant. The final #7 to #10 have been drilled around the Dead Otter Showing at 3.1 g/t to the south of the western side of DOL. This means that they have drilled a linear length of circa 3.5 km’s on a sub 1000m pilot drill programme! That’s a great result in itself! ……..and EVERY drill core shows potential mineralisation! The potential at North Hemlo could be very significant. Pity they couldn’t have sneaked just one cheeky assay out of Actlabs pre Christmas!!

data.author: char71
data.content: It is looking good! Shares in issue now versus work done since ipo of 10p which went to 18p so about 10p sounds achievable short term and multiples of that if hemlo becomes a new discovery, look at GGP who did over 2000% on their discovery amd this is also positioned well. Near the mine and infrastructure, not to deep either, in fact only a fraction of the depth GGP had to drill to for theirs. data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Drilling restarted last week after a temporary cessation just after NH_25_09. In the RNS (now 11 days ago) Fcm confirmed that the intention was to recommence drilling last week to complete the planned programme before Christmas. We know already that they were talking about ‘surpassing’ the planned meterage (700m). They should be pretty much finished in the next day or two if not already? Fcm confirmed that “ the geological features observed to date reinforce our confidence in the Dead Otter trend as a compelling gold target within the North Hemlo Project. We look forward to receiving the first assay results in the New Year”. So, whilst no assays yet (200 samples have already gone to Actlabs), the team are clearly liking what they see in the core. The terminology used suggests a pretty high degree of confidence in what the lab analysis might show. In addition, although this is a pilot or ‘first pass’ drill programme, I am especially pleased to see that they have the confidence to exceed the meterage before any assays are received confirming that they are positive for au. Again, this tends to reaffirm that high degree of confidence, as dd drilling at even near surface is a costly exercise especially in the relatively high risk world of a first or maiden drill programme on a project area. Can’t wait for first results.

data.author: Big_kahuna
data.content: There is no takeover bid for First Class Metals. Administrators control ~33.5% of the shares and intend to dispose of that stake, likely via a block sale or strategic placement. Any sale would typically be done at a modest premium to market rather than at takeover levels. If priced sensibly, a block sale should not dilute existing shareholders and can be positive if it brings a funded, long-term holder. A full takeover would only become realistic after drilling success and a maiden resource. At this stage, this is structural positioning, not a bid.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: Interesting to see that new neighbours Hemlo Mining Corporation are continuing to bolster its Senior Leadership Team. Firstly, Garett Macdonald has been appointed Vice President Operations, and will also assume responsibilities of General Manager at the Hemlo Mine, supported by Deputy General Manager Dennis Bigras. In this role, Mr. Macdonald will report to Eric Tremblay, Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Macdonald is a professional mining engineer with over 30 years of industry experience in mine operations, project development and corporate leadership. In addition, Perry Blanchard has been appointed Vice President of Sustainability, bringing nearly 30 years of experience in environment, health and safety management in the mining industry. Most recently, Mr. Blanchard served as Vice President, Environment and Sustainability at Maritime Resources Corp., where he led the Hammerdown Project through environmental assessment, permitting, construction transition, and ultimately acquisition by New Found Gold Corp. in November 2025. It is clear that HMC mean business as it looks to establish itself as a leading Canadian mid-tier growth-focused gold producer, with an immediate focus on maximizing the value of the Hemlo Gold Mine's existing infrastructure through a fit-for-purpose operating approach, while unlocking new opportunities through “aggressive brownfields exploration.” There is little doubt in my mind that HMC is a very ambitious new company who do not intend simply sitting back and draining the vestiges of gold from the old Hemlo pit. They are exploring neighbouring areas, and so will be watching the activities of First Class Metals like a hawk. The results of our maiden scout drill programme on the DOT will be very much on their radar. It would be good to know if MS or JK have touched base with them yet. A Zoom chat over a cuppa and a Custard Cream would do no harm. Good assays and our timing akin to this news, as well as continued pog increases, could be absolutely perfect.

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: This is simply to do with transparency rules under the takeover code which requires notification of holdings above 1 per cent. This is done through the submission of Form 8.3. General market rules require notification when holdings exceed 3 per cent. Notification is then x TR1 which I suspect is where the confusion is coming. Form 8.3’s do not show increases or reductions in holdings as do TR1’s from time to time. 8.3’s simply show what is held at the time of the requirement if you are over one per cent.

Programme highlights 10 diamond drill holes completed ~3km of strike tested along the Dead Otter trend Drilling exceeded contracted metres Visually prospective geology in every hole Deformation, quartz veining & sulphides consistent with a Hemlo-style gold system 300+ samples already dispatched for assay Location matters North Hemlo sits in the world-class Hemlo Greenstone Belt (>23Moz Au produced). With Barrick’s US$1.09bn exit from Hemlo completed earlier this month, the district is firmly back in focus — and FCM’s Dead Otter trend lies directly alongside the new operator’s ground. Multiple gold styles remain in play, including: • Shear-hosted orogenic gold • Structurally controlled mineralisation at greenstone–granite contacts Assays will determine grade, but geology underpins value — and the geological evidence supports continued confidence in the Dead Otter trend. #FCM https://firstclassmetalsplc.com/announcements/7318908 https://x.com/i/status/2003370543559397745

data.author: Urbanracer
data.content: The below is a confirmation of the situation from July RNS. We know from interview with MS that we are waiting on LiDAR dataset review. Clearly Fcm are wanting to be in a position to report on the Sunbeam position in its entirety which makes sense. Also note that the OJEP grant app had been submitted by July with a focus on the Roy trend. · Extensive soil sampling programme completedOver 500 A-horizon samples collected across 4km of the Roy structure - now in the laboratory, targeting gold-in-soil anomalies along this key trend. · Very Low Frequency ("VLF")-magnetic survey192 stations across 3.8km of grid surveyed; data undergoing interpretation to refine targets ahead of possible drill planning. · Historic shafts located and sampledProspecting rediscovered the 113 feet deep B43 shaft, with grab samples showing visible chalcopyrite and galena. B45 not yet located. · Roy structural review suggests Hammond Reef-style potentialStructural report by Prof. M.L. Hill confirms key controls on Roy trend; further petrology and core review recommended. · LiDAR dataset under expert reviewThird-party consultants are interpreting terrain data to sharpen structural models across the broader corridor. · 2025 Ontario Junior Explorers Programmes ("OJEP") grant application submittedFourth consecutive year FCM has applied - this time focused on advancing the Roy zone following encouraging field results.

Also in the mix is the question of Zig Zag after another 14.6 per cent rise in the price of Lithium last week, and, of course, what could happen if NH results are good. Our new neighbour will be watching out for those like a hawk.

First Class Metals PLC
("First Class Metals", "FCM" or the "Company")
Rule 2.9 Announcement
In accordance with Rule 2.9 of the City Code on Takeovers and Mergers (the "Takeover Code" or "Code"), the Company confirms that, as at the date and time of this announcement, it had 249,171,836 ordinary shares of £0.001 each ("Shares") in issue.
In addition, the Company has in issue £282,500 2025 CLNs and £350,000 2026 CLNs convertible into Shares. The Company does not hold any shares in treasury.
Consequently, 251,449,552 is the figure which may be used by shareholders as the denominator for the calculation by which they will determine if they are required to notify their interest in, or a change to their interest in, FCM under the FCA's Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules.

Any offer, if made, will be made solely by certain offer documentation which will contain the full terms and conditions of any offer, including details of how it may be accepted.The release, distribution or publication of this announcement in whole or in part, directly or indirectly in, into or from jurisdictions outside the United Kingdom may be restricted by law and therefore persons into whose possession this announcement comes should inform themselves about, and observe, such restrictions. Any failure to comply with the restrictions may constitute a violation of the securities law of any such jurisdiction.
Disclosure requirements of the Code
Under Rule 8.3(a) of the Code, any person who is interested in 1% or more of any class of relevant securities of an offeree company or of any securities exchange offeror (being any offeror other than an offeror in respect of which it has been announced that its offer is, or is likely to be, solely in cash) must make an Opening Position Disclosure following the commencement of the offer period and, if later, following the announcement in which any securities exchange offeror is first identified. An Opening Position Disclosure must contain details of the person's interests and short positions in, and rights to subscribe for, any relevant securities of each of (i) the offeree company and (ii) any securities exchange offeror(s). An Opening Position Disclosure by a person to whom Rule 8.3(a) of the Code applies must be made by no later than 3.30 pm (London time) on the 10th business day following the commencement of the offer period and, if appropriate, by no later than 3.30 pm (London time) on the 10th business day following the announcement in which any securities exchange offeror is first identified. Relevant persons who deal in the relevant securities of the offeree company or of a securities exchange offeror prior to the deadline for making an Opening Position Disclosure must instead make a Dealing Disclosure.
Under Rule 8.3(b) of the Code, any person who is, or becomes, interested in 1% or more of any class of relevant securities of the offeree company or of any securities exchange offeror must make a Dealing Disclosure if the person deals in any relevant securities of the offeree company or of any securities exchange offeror. A Dealing Disclosure must contain details of the dealing concerned and of the person's interests and short positions in, and rights to subscribe for, any relevant securities of each of (i) the offeree company and (ii) any securities exchange offeror, save to the extent that these details have previously been disclosed under Rule 8 of the Code. A Dealing Disclosure by a person to whom Rule 8.3(b) of the Code applies must be made by no later than 3.30 pm (London time) on the business day following the date of the relevant dealing. If two or more persons act together pursuant to an agreement or understanding, whether formal or informal, to acquire or control an interest in relevant securities of an offeree company or a securities exchange offeror, they will be deemed to be a single person for the purpose of Rule 8.3 of the Code.
